qas.question: Roughly how many pages of the works of Aristotle were translated by the 12th century?
Richard Dales believes that the work of Aristotle represents the turning point of what?
What word described the early attempts to understand the work of Aristotle?
What faculty did scholars attempt to use to prove the thoughts of Aristotle?
What language did 12th century scholars studying Aristotle speak in?

plausible_answers.text: a spirit of inquiry into natural processes

qas.question: What began to emerge in the 1200's?
What is considered one of the most important discoveries in the world?
Who called the discovery of Aristotle's work a turning point in Western Science?
What focused on using Aristotelian logic to disprove the bible?
Roughly how many pages of the works of Richard Dales were translated by the 12th century?
What did Aristotle believe that the work of Richard Dales represent the turning point of?
What word described the early attempts to understand the work of Dales?
What faculty did scholars attempt to use to prove the thoughts of Aristotle?
What language did 12th century scholars studying Dale speak in?

context: <b6_0>The rediscovery of Aristotle's works<b6_0/>–<a0_0><b10_0>more than 3000 pages<b10_0/><a0_0/> of it would eventually be translated –fuelled <b5_0>a spirit of inquiry into natural processes<b5_0/> that had already begun to emerge in the 12th century. Some scholars believe that these works represented one of the most important document discoveries in Western intellectual history. <b7_0>Richard Dales<b7_0/>, for instance, calls the discovery of Aristotle's works "a turning point in the history of <a1_0><b11_0>Western thought<b11_0/><a1_0/>." After Aristotle re-emerged, <b8_0>a community of scholars<b8_0/>, primarily communicating in <a4_0><b14_0>Latin<b14_0/><a4_0/>, accelerated the process and practice of attempting to reconcile the thoughts of Greek antiquity, and especially ideas related to understanding the natural world, with those of the church. The efforts of this "<a2_0><b9_0><b12_0>scholasticism<b12_0/><b9_0/><a2_0/>" were focused on applying Aristotelian logic and thoughts about natural processes to biblical passages and attempting to prove the viability of those passages through <a3_0><b13_0>reason<b13_0/><a3_0/>. This became the primary mission of lecturers, and the expectation of students.
